column1: 06:45|Six-forty-five the shavers buzz and the Acutes line up in alphabetical order at the mirrors
column5: D. . . . The walking Chronics like me walk in when the Acutes are done
column6: then the Wheelers are wheeled in.|One Flew Over the Cuckoo’s Nest|Ken Kesey

column1: 06:45|The black boy’s dwarf head swivels and comes nose to knuckle with that hand. He frowns at it
column2: then takes a quick check where’s the other two black boys just in case
column3: and tells McMurphy they don’t open the cabinet till six-forty-five. “It’s a policy
column4: ” he says.|One Flew Over the Cuckoo’s Nest|Ken Kesey

column1: 06:45|As the clock pointed to a quarter to seven
column2: the dog woke and shook himself. After waiting in vain for the footman
column3: who was accustomed to let him out
column4: the animal wandered restlessly from one closed door to another on the ground floor; and
column5: returning to his mat in great perplexity
column7: with a long and melancholy howl.|No Name|Wilkie Collins

column1: 06:45|"He was still hurriedly thinking all this through
column2: unable to decide to get out of the bed
column3: when the clock struck quarter to seven. There was a cautious knock at the door near his head. ""Gregor""
column4: somebody called - it was his mother - ""it's quarter to seven. Didn't you want to go somewhere?"""|Metamorphosis|Franz Kafka

column1: 06:45|'It's six forty-five.' She stands in the doorway
column2: keeping both of her feet neatly aligned just behind the flaking red line from all those years ago.|Before I fall|Lauren Oliver
